MSE Symposium Considers
Crisis In American Spirit
BY SUNITA HANJURA

Independent Presidential Candidate John Anderson will be one
of the speakers at the symposium.

With the first lecture scheduled for Monday, October 6th,
the 14th Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium is designed to explore the causes of what many
see as America's current malaise
and to suggest possible paths to
recovery. The 1980 Symposium, entitled "The Crisis of the
American Spirit: An Evaluation
of Our Times", will attract
speakers such as John Anderson,
Norman Vincent Peale and Dr.
Henry Steele Commager, among
others, to the Homewood campus.
This year's Symposium was
organized by chairpersons Jeff

Milsteen, Joseph D. Biegel and
Corinne Mull, all three of whom
.are Political Science majors.
They describe the "crisis" as.
primarily one of morale. According to Mull, "Over the past
two decades, the American spirit
has been sloping downward in
all categories." In the past, they
say, the public's faith in the
country has always been restored. The Symposium chairpersons believe that the lack
of spirit at the present time is
also temporary. "There are all
these problems we have right
now, economic, international
etc.," says Biegel, "but in the
end, we can overcome them."

Gay Preference
To the Editor:
I am tired of the homophobic argument that the use of
the word Gay to describe those
men and wymen who follow a
certain lifestyle has somehow
corrupted the English language.
I am also tired of that argument
being made by people who do
not understand homosexuality
or the Gay community.
Homosexuality is a sexual
preference. Men or wymen are
homosexual if they desire phy-

sical relationships with members
of the same sex. They are
heterosexual if they prefer relationships with members of the
complementary sex. Some people are exclusively homosexual
or heterosexual; others are not
and are considered to be bisexual. An argument can be made
that most people are bisexual.
"
As you should have noticed
by now, homosexual, heterosexual, and bisexual are adjectives.
Since many people are, at least
potentially, bisexual, it is incorrect to use homosexual and
heterosexual as nouns. Yes, I
know they are commonly used
as such, but that does not
make it correct.
I noticed,
however, that you did not
consider this to be a corruption
of the language.
Gay is not a sexual preference; it is a lifestyle. The
adoption of the word Gay to
describe men and wymen with a
homosexual preference was not
made to find a short, nonderogatory word for a sexual
preference, but to describe a
way of life that is more than a
game of musical beds. Being
Gay is a political statement that
I do, or at least am trying
to, accept my homosexuality
and that I am part of a community of people like myself.
There are many homosexual
men and wymen who are not
Gay.
There are also Gay men and
wymen who are not homosexual. The Gay community also
encompasses transsexuals who
have similar problems but from a
different perspective. Believing
that Gay is simply a short,
non-derogatory work to describe
a sexual preference is a mistake
based on fuzzy ideas about a

community that most outsiders
choose to ignore.
The Johns Hopkins University Gay Caucus, despite its
missing campus notes, does exist
and continues to meet on
Wednesday nights in Levering
Hall's conference Room A. The
Caucus' purpose is to try to
correct the fuzzy ideas Hopkins
students have about Gay men
and wymen and to provide a
place for Gay men and wymen
to meet and gain support from
each other.
Finally, I am tired of the
argument against the use of the
word Gay being made by selfappointed language experts on
their own ideas of what is
proper. In my equally valid

The tragedy which claimed the
life of one Hopkins freshman,
David Wasserman, and injured
another when they jumped from
the back of a speeding pickup
truck is not over. The Delaware
State Police, who suspected the
survivor, Jonathan Katz, of
lying, have been trying to
corroborate his stories. So far,
no new witnesses have stepped
forward. The police are still
searching for the vehicle in
question.
According to Corporal Beck
of the Delaware State Police, the
details have been reviewed, and
what was called a traffic fatality
has been reclassified as a criminal incident. The suspects, still
unidentified, now could be tried
for attempted robbery, attempted kidnapping and possibly
manslaughter.
Cpl. Beck suspected Katz
was lying because of the conflicting accounts he gave the

police and the media. However,
after gathering information from
a third interview with Katz a
week ago Monday and from the
written statements of two witnesses who were driving behind
the pickup, Beck now thinks the
facts of the incident have been
established: Wasserman panicked
after after one person in the cab
threatened him and asked him
for money and then both
Wasserman and Katz jumped
from the truck. They did not fall
and were not pushed, Beck adds.
At present, the police are
searching for a white or light

blue compact, either a Chevy of
a foreign car. They have established that it was a Maryland
registered vehicle, but have only
the first letter of the license
plate, a "K"--not enough information to start a search through
vehicle registration files.
Katz has been recuperating
at home in Scarsdale,'NY after
being released from the hospital
September 9. When he returns to
Hopkins, Beck intends to interview him again, perhaps under
hypnosis and with a police
sketch artist in an effort to find
more leads.

Snobs vs. Slobs
On The Links
BY JUNIUS LOGAN
I have never mastered golf,
probably because I lack the skill and/or
patience to con an egg-sized ball across
acres of rolling lawn and into a hole no
bigger than a shot glass. Nevertheless, I
enjoyed Caddyshack and if you haven't
seen it, I urge you to do so, before it slips
into commercial limbo of T.V. sales and
distribution.
The action - rather the misadventures - take place at the Bushwood
Country Club, a snob preserve run by the
stiff Judge Sm ails (Ted Knight). He
and the rest of Bushwood's pompous elite
must contend with a plethora of kooks:
mainly Ty Webb (Chevy Chase), Al Czervick (Rodney Dangerfield), and a deranged assistant greenskeeper named Carl (Bill
Murray). In playing off Ted Knight,
these three brilliantly realize the film's
comic potential, which is firmly based in
the old Marx Brothers formula - propriety
takes a beating.
Caddyshack owes much of its
success to excellent casting, as each actor
plays a part tailored to his particular
expertise in timing, slapstick and caricature. Chase moves easily through the
dizzy maunderings of a Zen-indocrinated

playboy.
Dangerfield is mercilessly
funny as an ostentatious millionaire
developer, complete with a bright red
Rolls Royce, a gadget-ridden golf bag to
shame James Bond, and a propensity for
tossing money like rice at a wedding. Bill
Murray's cartoon-like guerilla war against
an annoying gopher benefits so much
from his believeability that the audience
is quickly drawn into this hilarious Tomand-Jerry schtik.
Remarkably, there is a purpose
beneath this insanity, as these three
bedevil Bushwood's upper-crustiness, not
particularly out of malice, but their
inability to fit in. As expressed by the
Judge, Caddyshack's theme is: "Some
people just don't belong."
The writers see no evil in this, and
champion the virtues of individuality
through Danny Newnen, a young caddy
ambivalent towards an impending college
education and a future in his father's
lumber yard. Eventually, conflict between social pressures and his own desires
result in an identity crisis and the formation of a love triangle which includes his
girlfriend and Smails' flirtatious bombshell niece. This plot line serves to unify
the seemingly disjointed antics of Chase,
Dangerfield and Murray. Fortunately,

the writers balanced the script so that
Danny's story does not strike the audience as a disturbing note of sentimentality in an otherwise light film.
If Caddyshack suffers at all, it is
from the cardboard nature of its female
characters. Though Smails' niece can
be excused, Danny's girlfriend could use
more dimension, or at least, what few
complexities she does possess could be
reworked into a combination which
makes sense. Her reaction to Danny's
infidelity is disappointingly mild and her
behavior during a later kink in their
romance prompts the audience to scratch
its heads.
A Joan Rivers, Mary Tyler Moore,
Carol Burnett, or some other comedienne
with enough presence to complement
Dangerfield, Chase or Murray would be a
welcome addition to the film. More and
more, women are taking up golf, and the
writers seem aware of this, as women
golfers appear as extras. Sadly, the comic
potential of a female gonzo golfer is
ignored - unfortunate as female viewers
are left to identify with Smelling's wild
niece or Danny's domesticated girlfriend.
This aside, eighteen holes" of
Caddyshack, with its charmingly crazed
characters, effective balance of dialogue

to action, and supportive score (Johnny
Mandel and Kenny Loggins) provides
solid entertainment and simple diversion
from the worries of low GPA's, troublesome work-study jobs and romantic
problems.
Isn't that the traditional purpose
of a summer movie?

nudity and minor vulgarity.
